Award.AwardTitle: Miniquasars in the Dark Ages: Cosmological simulations of black holes with radiative transfer
Award.AbstractNarration:
The epoch before and during reionization is about to become accessible observationally through a combination of infrared and radio instruments and fine scale microwave background experiments. Understanding the nature of sources that reheated and reionized the intergalactic medium at the end of the dark ages is therefore crucial. This project will investigate the role of quasars in the high redshift Universe, combining ab initio cosmological simulations of quasar and galaxy formation and growth with high resolution radiative transfer to perform the first fully self consistent modeling of this epoch. The contribution of quasars through both thermal feedback and ionizing radiation, so far largely missing in theoretical predictions, is likely to dominate the early stages and substantially modify the large scale structure seen in neutral hydrogen. The simulations will reveal the complex interplay of pre-ionization by hard X-ray sources and the contribution of stellar sources, study the physical state of intergalactic gas, and make detailed physically motivated predictions of the number and character of radio sources.

These results have major implications for what is seen later, from quasars and supermassive black holes to the large-scale structure traced by dwarf galaxies. As the first observational studies of the dark ages are just on the horizon, being part of a new, emerging field will benefit the graduate student and undergraduates involved in the research. The results will be incorporated in an existing outreach program working with middle school students from underrepresented groups, and included in undergraduate coursework projects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Survey astronomy, the mapping of large areas of the sky has enabled the study of galaxy and quasar formation in the nearby Universe to mature into a precise science. Current galaxy surveys at much earlier times, the epoch of the formation of the first galaxies and quasars have only been able to cover much smaller volumes, due to the small field of view of the Hubble Space Telescope.  Searches for the first objects (massive galaxies or quasars) are extremely difficult, because they are so rare, and statistics of a substantial population impossible to achieve so far. Similarly, numerical simulations of galaxy formation had been limited in the size of the volume they can evolve, so resulting models of early galaxy and quasar formation lack the dynamic range to cover both the formation of individual objects and make large scale statistical studies of them.

Throughout this project we have made use of the largest NSF supercomputers to run the first computer simulations of the end of "Dark ages" (the epoch before the first stars) that overcome these limitations.  We have developed our new cosmological hydrodynamic code  "MP-Gadget" so that it is able to run on the entirety of the 0.7 million compute cores of the Blue Waters supercomputer at the National Center for Supercomputer Applications. The code evolves the matter distribution in the Universe forward in time from shortly after the Big Bang, to the time a billion years later when galaxies form in abundance. New algorithms for including the force of gravity, and of hydrodynamics have been implemented, along with the mechanisms for star formation from molecular hydrogen and models for the transfer of radiation from the first miniquasars and stars. The simulated universe which is the culmination of this work is called "BlueTides". It contains hundreds of thousands of galaxies and miniquasars in a volume hundreds of times larger than both the previous largest computer model and the volume observed by space telescopes so far. 

In our computer models we have found that billion solar mass black holes like those that power the earliest and brightest quasars seen are able to form naturally, without needing exotic physics. We have been able to make statistical studies of the luminosities of simulated galaxies, and quasars, showing that they are consistent with what has been observed so far, and helping to understand the physical processes that create them. More importantly we have been able to predict what upcoming telescopes should see. NASA satellites such as the James Webb Space Telescope will observe much fainter galaxies, so that we will be able to compare with the huge population of small galaxies predicted by the simulation and make powerful statistical tests of cosmology and models for how stars and quasars form. Other space telescopes such as the upcoming Wide Field Infrared Survey Telescope (WFIRST) will survey much greater areas of sky (by factors of thousands), and this is where the predictions of BlueTides are even more exciting. We have found that WFIRST should be able to discover thousands of galaxies with the mass of our Milky Way, but at a time when the Universe was only 5 percent of it's present age. The simulation predicts that these galaxies (which had never been modeled before because they are rare) should be perfect disk galaxies, like the spiral galaxies seen in the nearby, late Universe. This was extremely surprising, as until then, this early epoch in the Universe was believed to be chaotic, and crowded,  with many small irregular shaped galaxies colliding and merging and certainly no "grand design" galaxies like the Milky Way. That such galaxies can form means that they will be amazing targets for future instruments and the simplicity of their structure will mean that tests of cosmology and galaxy formation can be designed around them. We have also found that tests of dark energy using "baryon oscillations" (a standard ruler) will be possible at early times, which will help guide instrument design.

The work with the various large computer models over the course of the project had a broad impact, with several press releases and media articles. This included the PI being interviewed for Japanese and Italian television, the work being the subject of a cover story in Sky and Telescope Magazine spread over two issues, Jan and Feb 2017. Several public lectures have been given on the work, and outreach projects with middle school children in Pittsburgh have been carried out. Web resources have been generated for the project and the public is invited to visit the BlueTides web page http://bluetides-project.org/ and also to visually explore one of our earlier simulations in the project using Gigapan web technology  ( http://gigapan.com/gigapans/76215/ ) So far over 64,000 people have explored the simulated universe, hunting for quasars and galaxies with their web browsers.
